sen.j: 宇田川 玄真（うだがわ げんしん、明和6年12月28日 (旧暦)（1770年1月24日） - 天保5年12月4日 (旧暦)（1835年1月2日））は、江戸時代後期の蘭方医。
sen.e: Genshin UDAGAWA (January 24, 1770 - January 2, 1835) was a Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) who lived during the late Edo period.
Genshin UDAGAWA (January 24, 1770 - January 2, 1835) was a Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) who lived during the late Edo period.
Genshin UDAGAWA (January 24, 1770 - January 2, 1835) was a Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) who lived during the late Edo period.

sen.j: 本姓は安岡、名は璘。
sen.e: His real name was Rin YASUOKA.
His real name was Rin YASUOKA.
His real name was Rin YASUOKA.

sen.j: 玄真は字。
sen.e: His was commonly known as Genshin.
Genshin was his azana (name used after becoming an adult).
Genshin was his azana (name used after becoming an adult).

sen.j: 榛斎と号 (称号)す。
sen.e: He was also known under the name of Shinsai.
He called himself Shinsai.
He called himself Shinsai.

sen.j: 養父は宇田川玄随、養子に宇田川榕菴。
sen.e: Genzui UDAGAWA was his adopted father and Yoan UDAGAWA was his adopted son.
Genzui UDAGAWA was his adoptive father and Yoan UDAGAWA was his adopted son.
sen.cmt: よく見る訳に直します。
sen.e: Genzui UDAGAWA was his adoptive father and Yoan UDAGAWA was his adopted son.

sen.j: 江戸蘭学における大槻玄沢の実質的後継者。
sen.e: He followed in the footsteps of Gentaku OTSUKI in the discipline of Western studies in the Edo area.
He was the practical successor to Gentaku OTSUKI in the world of Western studies of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 原文に近いかたちに直します。
sen.e: He was the practical successor to Gentaku OTSUKI in the world of Western studies of the Edo period.

sen.j: 門弟に吉田長淑、藤井方亭、坪井信道、佐藤信淵、緒方洪庵、川本幸民、箕作阮甫、飯沼慾斎、青地林宗らがいる。
sen.e: His disciples included Choshuku YOSHIDA, Hotei FUJII, Shindo TSUBOI, Nobuhiro SATO, Koan OGATA, Komin KAWAMOTO, Genpo MITSUKURI, Yokusai IINUMA, and Rinso AOCHI.
His disciples included Choshuku YOSHIDA, Hotei FUJII, Shindo TSUBOI, Nobuhiro SATO, Koan OGATA, Komin KAWAMOTO, Genpo MITSUKURI, Yokusai IINUMA, and Rinso AOCHI.
His disciples included Choshuku YOSHIDA, Hotei FUJII, Shindo TSUBOI, Nobuhiro SATO, Koan OGATA, Komin KAWAMOTO, Genpo MITSUKURI, Yokusai IINUMA, and Rinso AOCHI.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 玄真は明和6年（1769年）伊勢国安岡家に生まれる。
sen.e: Genshin was born to the Yasuoka family of Ise Province in 1769.
Genshin was born to the Yasuoka family of Ise Province in 1769.
Genshin was born to the Yasuoka family of Ise Province in 1769.

sen.j: 若くして杉田玄白の私塾・天真楼、その弟子大槻玄沢の私塾・芝蘭堂で学び芝蘭堂四天王筆頭と称された。
sen.e: While yet at an early age, he studied at Tenshinro, the private school of Genpaku SUGITA, and then entered Gentaku OTSUKI's Shiran-do, where he came to be known as the Shiran-do Big Four.

While yet at an early age, he studied at Tenshinro, the private school of Genpaku SUGITA, and then entered Shirando, the private school of Gentaku OTSUKI who was a pupil of Genpaku, and he was called the head of Shirando Big Four.

While yet at an early age, he studied at Tenshinro, the private school of Genpaku SUGITA, and then entered Shirando, the private school of Gentaku OTSUKI who was a pupil of Genpaku, and he was called the head of Shirando Big Four.

sen.j: 一時杉田玄白の娘と結婚、養子となったが離縁される（若気の至りか放蕩を重ねた故といわれる）。
sen.e: He was adopted by Genpaku SUGITA by marrying his daughter but soon got disowned (it is said to have been attributable to Genshin's debauchery or the fact that their marriage was an impulsive one as they were young.)
He was adopted by Genpaku SUGITA by marrying his daughter, however soon got disowned (as for the reason, it is said that Genshin had indulged in dissipation probably because he had been still young).
sen.cmt: 誤訳です。「若気の至りか」は「or」ではなく、「若気の至りでなのかわからないけれども放蕩したから」というふうに後の節に続きます。
sen.e: He was adopted by Genpaku SUGITA by marrying his daughter, however soon got disowned (as for the reason, it is said that Genshin had indulged in dissipation probably because he had been still young).

sen.j: 寛政9年（1798年）、芝蘭堂の高弟宇田川玄随が亡くなると宇田川家の当主として養子に入りその跡を継いだ。
sen.e: In 1798, on the death of Genzui UDAGAWA, who was Shirando's most able disciple, he was adopted by the Udagawa family and took over as head of the family.
In 1798, on the death of Genzui UDAGAWA, who was Shirando's most able disciple, he was adopted by the Udagawa family and took over as head of the family.
In 1798, on the death of Genzui UDAGAWA, who was Shirando's most able disciple, he was adopted by the Udagawa family and took over as head of the family.

sen.j: のちに改暦に悩む江戸幕府からの要請で天文台の蘭書（西洋の学術書）翻訳員として招聘され和蘭書籍和解御用方としてフランスのノエル・ショメールが編纂した百科事典の翻訳に携わった。
sen.e: He was invited to take a post as translator of Western academic books on the astronomical observatory by the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which was considering a revision of the calendar, and then, as a Dutch book translator, worked on the translation of an encyclopedia originally compiled by Noel Chomel, French scholar.

He was invited to take a post as translator of Western academic books on the astronomical observatory by the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which was considering a revision of the calendar, and then, as a Dutch book translator, worked on the translation of an encyclopedia originally compiled by Noel Chomel, French scholar.

He was invited to take a post as translator of Western academic books on the astronomical observatory by the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which was considering a revision of the calendar, and then, as a Dutch book translator, worked on the translation of an encyclopedia originally compiled by Noel Chomel, French scholar.

sen.j: また玄真が開いた私塾・風雲堂は医学のみならず、化学、科学、自然哲学など幅広い分野で日本の礎を築いていくことになり蘭学中期の大立者と賞賛された。
sen.e: He was praised as a titan of Western studies who laid the foundations for the nation in the mid-Edo period by teaching a wide range of areas at his private school, Fuun-do, including medical science, chemistry, science, and natural philosophy.

Besides Genshin's private school Fuundo laid the foundations not only of medical science but also of wide range of fields including chemistry, science, and natural philosophy, and he was praised as the titan of the middle period of Western studies.
sen.cmt: 誤訳、訳漏れがあります。
sen.e: Besides Genshin's private school Fuundo laid the foundations not only of medical science but also of wide range of fields including chemistry, science, and natural philosophy, and he was praised as the titan of the middle period of Western studies.

sen.j: 天保5年（1835年）12月4日死去。
sen.e: He died in December 4, 1835.
He died on December 4, 1835.
He died on December 4, 1835.

sen.j: 享年67。
sen.e: He was 67 years old.
He was at the age of 67.
He was at the age of 67.

sen.j: 玄真は蘭方医として蘭学の発展に尽くし日本初の蘭日辞書ハルマ和解の編纂にも参加。
sen.e: Genshin devoted himself to the flourishing of Western studies as a Ranpoi and compiled the Haruma Wage (Halma Explained in Japanese), the first Dutch-Japanese dictionary ever published in Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Genshin devoted himself to the development of Western studies as a Ranpoi and was also involved in the compilation of the Halma Wage (Dutch-Japanese Dictionary based on the dictionary by Halma), the first Dutch-Japanese dictionary in Japan.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Genshin devoted himself to the development of Western studies as a Ranpoi and was also involved in the compilation of the Halma Wage (Dutch-Japanese Dictionary based on the dictionary by Halma), the first Dutch-Japanese dictionary in Japan.

sen.j: 訳書の中で蜂蜜酒とその製法を紹介したことでも知られる。
sen.e: He is also known to have introduced honey liquor and its recipe in his translation corpus.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He is also known to have introduced honey liquor and its recipe in his translation corpus.
He is also known to have introduced honey liquor and its recipe in his translation corpus.

sen.j: また、養父玄随の訳した『西説内科撰要』の増補改訂版を作成し、分泌器官に用いる「腺」や膵臓の「膵」の字など医学用語を作成（字を発見し当てはめたわけではなく造字した）したのも玄真の功績の一つである。
sen.e: He also revised and enlarged the "Seiyo Naika Senyo" (Selected Points of Western Theories on Internal Medicine) that had been translated by his adopted father, Genzui UDAGAWA, and invented some of the Japanese characters used to describe medical terms, including '腺' and '膵' that refer to the secretory organs and pancreas, respectively.

He also revised and enlarged the "Seisetsu Naika Senyo" (Selected Points of Western Theories on Internal Medicine) that had been translated by his adoptive father Genzui, and invented new characters for describing medical terms (he did not apply some Chinese characters which had already existed to new concepts, he practically made new characters [although those look like Chinese characters even to Chinese and Japanese]) including '腺' which refers to secretor and '膵' which refers to pancreas; this was one of Genshin's epoch-making achievements.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ、読み間違いがあります。オリジナルに「西訳内科…」とありましたが「西説」が正しいので直します。
sen.e: He also revised and enlarged the "Seisetsu Naika Senyo" (Selected Points of Western Theories on Internal Medicine) that had been translated by his adoptive father Genzui, and invented new characters for describing medical terms (he did not apply some Chinese characters which had already existed to new concepts, he practically made new characters [although those look like Chinese characters even to Chinese and Japanese]) including '腺' which refers to secretor and '膵' which refers to pancreas; this was one of Genshin's epoch-making achievements.

sen.j: 杉田玄白、前野良沢らが訳した解体新書は江戸蘭学、日本解剖学の基礎を築いたが、その後継者大槻玄沢がより正確な訳と版画凹版画を用いたものに改良した「重訂解体新書」を刊行するなど解剖学ではその改善に留まる。
sen.e: The Kaitai Shinsho (the historic Japanese translation of a Dutch anatomical text) translated by Genpaku SUGITA, Ryotaku MAENO, et al. laid the foundation of Western studies in Edo area and anatomy in Japan and later on their disciple, Gentaku OTSUKI, retranslated and published the revised edition of Kaitai Shinsho, which included copper-plate etchings for charts.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy) translated by Genpaku SUGITA, Ryotaku MAENO and others had laid the foundation of Western studies of the Edo period and of anatomy of Japan, and later, their disciple Gentaku OTSUKI had published the revised edition of Kaitai Shinsho with better translation and illustrations by copper-plate etchings, however, the development of anatomy had not much advanced since then.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミス、訳漏れがあります。
sen.e: The Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy) translated by Genpaku SUGITA, Ryotaku MAENO and others had laid the foundation of Western studies of the Edo period and of anatomy of Japan, and later, their disciple Gentaku OTSUKI had published the revised edition of Kaitai Shinsho with better translation and illustrations by copper-plate etchings, however, the development of anatomy had not much advanced since then.

sen.j: 玄真は最新のオランダ解剖学書を次々と訳し亜欧堂田善に解剖図を依頼して独自の解剖学訳書「和蘭内景医範提網」を刊行。
sen.e: Genshin vigorously translated numerous up-to-date Dutch anatomy books and published a translation of an anatomy text under the name of the 'Waran Naikei Ihan Teimo' (Medical Examples in Outline) supplemented with anatomical charts made by Denzen AODO.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Genshin vigorously translated numerous up-to-date Dutch anatomy books, besides he commissioned a famous painter Denzen AODO to make illustrations and published an original translation of an anatomy text 'Waran Naikei Ihan Teimo' (Medical Examples in Outline) with Denzen's illustrations.

Genshin vigorously translated numerous up-to-date Dutch anatomy books, besides he commissioned a famous painter Denzen AODO to make illustrations and published an original translation of an anatomy text 'Waran Naikei Ihan Teimo' (Medical Examples in Outline) with Denzen's illustrations.

sen.j: 「重訂解体新書」を越えるベストセラーになり「解体新書」、「重訂解体新書」と並ぶ日本初期解剖学史を代表する訳書として絶賛された。
sen.e: The book became a bestseller, which exceeded the sales of the revised edition of Kaitai Shinsho, and, together with the Kaitai Shinsho and its revised edition, the book was highly acclaimed as a leading translation work in the early stage of anatomical history in Japan.

The book became a bestseller, which exceeded the sales of the revised edition of Kaitai Shinsho, and, together with the Kaitai Shinsho and its revised edition, the book was highly acclaimed as a leading translation work in the early stage of anatomical history in Japan.

The book became a bestseller, which exceeded the sales of the revised edition of Kaitai Shinsho, and, together with the Kaitai Shinsho and its revised edition, the book was highly acclaimed as a leading translation work in the early stage of anatomical history in Japan.

sen.j: 遠西医範（オランダ解剖学書を訳した三十冊に及ぶ大著）
sen.e: Ensei Ihan (Examples from Western Medicine): Translation of a Dutch anatomical book, and it counts 30 volumes
Ensei Ihan (Examples from Western Medicine): Translation of a Dutch anatomical book, and it counts 30 volumes
Ensei Ihan (Examples from Western Medicine): Translation of a Dutch anatomical book, and it counts 30 volumes

sen.j: 和蘭内景医範提網（遠西医範の要約本。解体新書に並ぶと評された解剖学書）
sen.e: Waran Naikei Ihan Teimo (Medical Examples in Outline): Summary of the Ensei Ihan. A highly acclaimed anatomy book that compared with the Kaitai Shinsho.
Waran Naikei Ihan Teimo (Medical Examples in Outline): Summary of the Ensei Ihan and an anatomy book which was acclaimed that it could rival the Kaitai Shinsho
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Waran Naikei Ihan Teimo (Medical Examples in Outline): Summary of the Ensei Ihan and an anatomy book which was acclaimed that it could rival the Kaitai Shinsho

sen.e: Ensei Iho Meibutsuko (Supplement to the Treatise on Far Western Medicaments) - his adopted son, Yoan UDAGAWA, was the coauthor of the book.
Ensei Iho Meibutsuko (Study on the Far Western Medicine): Co-written with his adopted son, Yoan UDAGAWA
